Let's talk a little about your technique, because you have a, such a big sound with so much stuff going on out of that guitar.
What are you doing with your picking hand?
Well, I kind of play with a flatpick, and I play fingerstyle, as well - a pick and two other fingers.
It's a very convenient, useful thing.
There are some things you can do that you can't do with any other style.
You can do double rhythm on the bottom strings.
You know, if you're a solo accompanist, it's good to be able to make a big noise, you know, so we use it just to make it sound more orchestral; to make it more interesting.
For as long as you been playing guitar, are you still finding new things out about it?
Does it still have things to teach you when you sit down to play?

I think if you stop thinking that you're going to find new things every day then you might as well give up and go fishing or something, because the music has to be exploratory and you have to be finding new things.
What kinds of new things do you find?
I did some classical lessons very early on, but there's big gaps, so I'm always trying to learn about harmony.

And, you know, the last five years or so I've been listening to classical composers, you know, people like people like Benjamin Britten, Shostakovich - just because I love the kind of harmony and the kind of dissonance that they put into their music.
And I'm thinking well, I can borrow some of that.
I could steal bits of that.
It's a long and noble tradition, that stealing thing.
But, you know, at the same time I'm rooted in a very folky tradition.
So if I slip these ideas in there, they're kind of fleeting and passing because I'm just still an entertainer and, you know, it's basically three chords.
Well, there's C, F and G or there's, you know, there's weird ones.
You could do three weird chords, I suppose if you wanted to.
